data.text:
This is the question we got asked most in 2025: â€œWhy does my LLM-as-a-judge give me a 4 one day and a 3 the next for the exact same response?â€

But most of the time, thatâ€™s not actually the problem. The real issue is that weâ€™re asking one number to capture â€œqualityâ€ for something thatâ€™s inherently open-ended.

When you write an eval like â€œrate this response 1â€“5 for overall qualityâ€ and run it on a long or creative conversation, the model isnâ€™t confused â€” itâ€™s noticing that there are multiple reasonable ways the answer could go. Different tone, different structure, different emphasis. All valid. A single scalar just canâ€™t express that, so the score moves around and we blame the judge.

What worked much better for me was stopping the hunt for one perfect score and breaking quality into dimensions that actually match how humans evaluate responses. Accuracy, helpfulness, creativity, brevity. Suddenly a â€œ3â€ isnâ€™t bad or good on its own, it has context. A response can be low-creativity and still be exactly right for a user who just wants speed and clarity.

I also donâ€™t recommend to rely on one judge. Running a small ensemble and paying attention to disagreement turns out to be really useful. When judges split 5/3/4, thatâ€™s usually a sign the query is pluralistic, not that something is broken. (P.S: if you build a set of judges and look at overall trends, this is where automation benefits you!)

The key shift is focusing less on individual scores and more on trends. I donâ€™t care whether something is a 3.8 or a 4.2 â€” I care if helpfulness is trending down over 100 evals, or if variance is increasing because the system is producing more diverse responses.

So instead of â€œthis eval is flaky,â€ the better framing is â€œthis query allows multiple valid answers, and variance is the signal.â€ Once you make that shift, evals stop feeling brittle and start feeling like something you can actually build on.

P.S: Linking the Paper that's backing this up! "Artificial Hivemind: The Open-Ended Homogeneity of Language Models" which analyzed 26K real-world queries and revealed how homogeneous model responses actually are (71-82% similarity across different model families, even for open-ended questions). Worth a read if you're building eval systems.

Hamel Husain has been publishing eval flashcards, and the latest one was a great reminder of a core value weâ€™re pushing hard at Coval.

Even with the best automated evaluation infrastructure, human feedback is non-negotiable.

Hamel breaks down three evaluator types - code-based assertions, LLM-as-a-judge, and guardrails - and the taxonomy is spot on. But the key takeaway for me isnâ€™t which evaluators to use. Itâ€™s how you keep them honest.

Automated evals only create value if theyâ€™re calibrated against human judgment.

You can have:
â€¢ Perfect JSON checks
â€¢ Sophisticated LLM judges
â€¢ Carefully tuned guardrails

â€¦but if those metrics drift from what humans actually care about, they stop being signals and start being noise.

At Coval, we see this constantly with voice and chat agents:
â€¢ Human review surfaces what actually matters to users
â€¢ That feedback informs which failures are worth tracking
â€¢ And automated evals scale only after theyâ€™re aligned with real judgment (annotations & metric calibration)

Automated evals donâ€™t replace humans, they amplify them.

If youâ€™re building agent systems and your metrics arenâ€™t grounded in human feedback, youâ€™re not evaluating quality; youâ€™re just measuring activity.

Thanks to Hamel for the crisp reminder. This is exactly the direction the ecosystem needs to keep pushing.

Excited to announce that Coval has joined Zoom's ISV Exchange Program as a vendor! ðŸŽ‰

--> Why this matters:
Voice AI requires proof of performance, not just feature demos. Organizations need validation that Zoom Virtual Agents will handle their specific scenarios - different accents, background noise, knowledge base queries, compliance requirements - to ensure confidence at scale. Coval provides the independent testing layer that proves it works across thousands of real-world scenarios impossible to validate manually.

Coval empowers every team to validate quality in one unified platform:
--> Conversation designers track dialogue effectiveness
--> Product managers monitor goal completion
--> Engineers perform regression testing
--> Operations teams ensure compliance

A huge thank you to Jared Dennison, Ram R., Laura Ball, Andy Mazid, Kentis Gopalla, and the entire Zoom team working on this partnership; our early customers who helped us understand the demo-to-production gap, and everyone at Zoom scaling voice AI evaluation and QA - your feedback shaped how we built validation infrastructure for production deployments!

This is a big deal. Waymo just launched their Safety Hub, publishing transparent, ongoing data about autonomous driving performance.

Trust in autonomous systems doesnâ€™t come from marketing claims. It comes from measurable, auditable performance over time and the willingness to expose that data publicly.

Waymo learned this early in self-driving:
 â€¢ Instrument everything
 â€¢ Simulate edge cases relentlessly
 â€¢ Track safety metrics continuously
 â€¢ Share results clearly and consistently

That same lesson now applies to AI agents, especially voice and customer-facing systems. As agents become more autonomous, trust becomes a product feature, not a PR exercise.

The companies that win wonâ€™t just ship agents faster. Theyâ€™ll be the ones who can answer, with data:
 â€¢ How does the agent perform under stress?
 â€¢ Where does it fail?
 â€¢ How is it improving week over week?

Transparent evaluation builds confidence internally, with regulators, and most importantly with users.

This is the bar for autonomous systems going forward.

ðŸ§µ This week in Conversational AI

Surge week! So many pieces of the voice + AI ecosystem moved at once, from core model leaps to infra and real-world deployments.

OpenAI had a huge week, dropping both GPT-5.2 and the new State of Enterprise AI report. 

Google also stepped forward on two fronts: Translate now streams real-time translations directly into your headphones (wild that this is just becoming normal tech), and the company unveiled its deepest research agent yet, a sign of how fast agentic systems are maturing across the industry.

Deepgram announced its EU Endpoint is now GA, giving teams a fully EU-hosted path for compliant, low-latency speech workloads. Important building block as voice apps continue to globalize.

Rime & Hathora made their partnership official, bringing Rimeâ€™s Arcana model designed for real conversational interaction onto Hathoraâ€™s developer platform. Love seeing more infrastructure built explicitly for natural, back-and-forth voice.

ElevenLabs had another milestone moment, teaming up with Meta to bring expressive, scalable audio to Instagram, Horizon, and more unlocking natural voice for billions. Between this and the rapid product cadence theyâ€™ve been on, itâ€™s clear the audio layer of the internet is changing fast. 

Prepared launched a video/podcast series with super impactful insights! They just shared a powerful real-world save this week, where instant AI-generated context helped a 911 dispatcher identify a heart attack from a hangup call. These are the stories that remind us why reliability in voice systems matters so much.

Researchers at the University of Washington debuted AI headphones that automatically detect who youâ€™re talking to and isolate their voice â€” using just a few seconds of audio. A fascinating preview of attention-aware audio hardware.

What did we miss?

"How hard can voice AI testing be?"

Famous last words from every team that tries to build it in-house.

Mike at Krew gets it now. They're running voice agents in credit servicing -regulated as hell. Their team initially thought about building their own eval infrastructure. Then reality hit.

Testing voice AI isn't like testing software. You're not checking if a button works. You're measuring what humans actually perceive --> latency, naturalness, whether your agent sounds like a robot having a stroke.

"It's actually not that much easier than building self-driving cars. You just don't have to deal with physics." Mike went from exploring options to running tens of thousands of evals on Coval within 60 days. Now they're using our third-party reports to speed through bank procurement cycles.

The teams winning enterprise deals in regulated spaces? They can prove their agents work. With receipts. From a third party. Watch Mike explain why building this yourself is harder than it looks & check out our case-study blog!

Our team at Picogrid is launching a historic $500,000 corporate partnership with Cameron Universityâ€”the largest commercial program in the schoolâ€™s history.

Anchored by our presence at FISTA Innovation Park, this initiative connects professors and students directly with our engineers. We want to give back to the community by offering local talent a unique chance to experience life inside a high-growth defense startup.

Lawton-Fort Sill has welcomed us with open arms, and it means a lot to me personally that we can reinvest in this community.

I want to personally thank Dr. Shane Hunt and Dr. Krista Ratliff for their vision. Itâ€™s rare to find partners who move this fast and care this deeply about the city, state, and nation's success.

This partnership is a key part of our long-term plans in Lawton-Fort Sill! ðŸš€

Link to the full announcement is in the comments!

author.headline: Co-Founder at Picogrid | Growth | ex-McKinsey, U.S. Army ERDC

resharedPost.text:
When I started helping companies build AI products several years ago, I noticed a consistent pattern. Everyone was stuck in vibe-check hell.Â  Everyone had the same questions:

- How do I switch to a newer model and ensure everything still works?Â 
- What's the right granularity and division of labor for my agents?Â 
- How do I debug a system with lots of tool calls and handoffs? What do I even focus on first?Â 
- When I change my prompt, how do I know I'm not inadvertently breaking something else?
- How do I tune my retrieval or RAG database properly?

The answer lies in systematically measuring your AI product. The challenge is that AI systems are stochastic, so you need a new approach.Â  Thankfully, there are existing practices from machine learning that we can bring to AI engineering that are more accessible than you think.Â That is why Shreya Shankar decided to create the course AI Evals for Engineers and PMs, which has taught over 3,000 students from over 500 companies like Amazon, WalMart, Meta, Fidelity, OpenAI, Google and more. 

The January 2026 cohort of AI Evals for Engineers and PMs is now open. Seats are limited: https://lnkd.in/gMb6XXGU

author.headline: ML Engineer with 20 years of experience helping companies with AI

data.text: fyi in case you were wondering what we do

Starting my annual campaign to convince you that "improve voice AI evals" needs to be on your 2026 resolution list.

I'm like that friend who keeps telling you to go to the gym, except instead of the gym it's "please test your voice agent more than once before shipping."

This is how 2025 looked like for most voice-AI teams:
- Failing 40% of the time in production
- Your support team drowning in tickets
- You debugging at 2am trying to figure out why it worked in testing

Here's the uncomfortable truth: your agent probably works... sometimes. Maybe 70% of the time. Maybe 85%. But you ran it once, it worked, and you called it done.
Campaign promise for 2026: If you test your voice agent like actual messy humans are going to use it (background noise! interruptions! people who say "um" seventeen times!), you'll ship way less broken stuff.

Less broken stuff = less firefighting = more time to actually build cool things.

P.S: Let me know if you need help with your 2026 Voice AI Testing strategy. Happy to share best practices and will be sharing some gold nuggets here in the next couple of days as well!

ðŸ§µ This week in Conversational AI

I had to refresh TechCrunch a couple of times because I couldn't believe my eyes...I think this was the biggest early stage Voice AI round I've seen this year! Kyutai came out of stealth & raised $70M for a dual-stream "text-hidden" architecture that runs silent reasoning tokens alongside audio processing, solving voice AI's IQ vs. EQ trade-off with full-duplex capability at 1.1 kbps. Curious where this goes & congrats on this massive round! 

Speaking of funding, another round: Wispr Flow secured an additional $25 million in funding following rapid commercial traction, bringing total investment to $81 million and valuing the startup at $700 million post-money. Crazy! But the best part is that their funding actually is backed up by massive growth: they're used inside 270 Fortune 500 companies (!) and adding 125 new enterprise customers per week. The app has seen 40% month-over-month growth, and users now generate more than half of their typed characters through voice after three months of adoption. 

Pipecat Smart Turn v3.1 shipped with new English + Spanish human-labeled datasets and a GPU-oriented model, big upgrade for anyone chasing natural, interruption-aware voice turn detection.

Retell AI & Cartesia announced a partnership! Their announcement talks about impressive new performance marks: 2â€“3Ã— lower latency, <0.1% pronunciation error rate, and 99.9% uptime across thousands of concurrent calls, raising the bar for high-stakes verticals.

ElevenLabs on the cover of Forbes! "How A Tiny Polish Startup Became The Multi-Billion-Dollar Voice Of AI" is a great article that shows how a European Startup has massive impact all over the world. Contrats to Mati! ElevenLabs also launched 25 Days of Agents, teaming with Cloudflare, Railway, Vercel, Hugging Face, and more to drop daily deals for builders all month long. Make sure to follow along to sneak some great discounts! 

What did I miss?

Earlier this year, Coval was recruited as part of a community of AI experts and leaders to host a comprehensive course on voice agents and multimodal AI.

Daily is now now sharing the full recordings! It's a super valuable course for anyone building in voice AI.

Sharing a link to the Evals session below!

Most voice AI demos are basically fraud. Not legal fraud. But the "works perfectly in the demo room" kind that dies on contact with real users.

You spend months perfecting demos with:
--> Crystal clear audio
--> Patient users who never interrupt
--> Perfectly scripted paths
--> Zero background noise

Then you launch to humans who:
--> Talk over the agent
--> Have accents your model hasn't seen
--> Ask three questions at once
--> Change their mind mid-sentence
--> Call from noisy restaurants

Your "95% accuracy" agent starts getting 1-star reviews. The truth is that if you're not testing with realistic simulationsâ€”interruptions, noise, accents, chaos, you're not testing. You're hoping.
The gap between your demo and production is where customer trust dies.

Let's talk about it!  I'm joining David Zhao from LiveKit and Fabian Seipel  from ai-coustics on December 10th at frontiertower SF for 'The Audio Layer' - tackling one question: What does it take to make #VoiceAI actually work?

ðŸŽŸï¸ Limited space - RSVP in comments!

Stop hiring ML engineers. Start hiring product people who can read transcripts.
Controversial? Maybe.

But Hamel Husain told me something that completely shifts how I think about voice AI teams. The limiting factor for every voice AI product isn't the technology. It's whether someone is actually analyzing where it fails.

Everyone wants automated evals; LLM judges scoring everything; 
Dashboards with real-time metrics... 

But automation is a trap if you don't know what you're looking for.
Hamel sees that teams automate testing before they understand their failures.
They get clean dashboards showing "87% success rate." but then they have NO IDEA what's actually going wrong in the other 13%.

The breakthrough teams do this differently:
â†’ They have a "benevolent dictator" who reviews 50-100 real conversations
â†’ They journal patterns like a qualitative researcher
â†’ They identify failure modes unique to their product
â†’ THEN they automate

This is why Hamel says 60-80% of development time should be on evaluation.
Not writing code; but actually understanding where your product breaks.

At Coval, the customers who succeed aren't the ones with the most automated tests. They're the ones with someone who owns error analysis and won't let an issue ship until they understand why it's happening.

Is anyone on your team actually reviewing your voice AI failures?
Or are you just hoping your dashboards will tell you what to fix?

Thank you for being such a great guest on "Conversations in Conversational AI" â†’ link to full episode in comments.

ðŸ§µ This week in Conversational AI

What a week! The space keeps moving fast across open source, reliability, and real-time agent tech. Here are the drops and milestones that stood out ðŸ‘‡

Coval x Twilio teamed up for a deep dive into Voice AI reliability + evaluation, mapping how model metrics like WER and latency connect to real business outcomes. A big step toward making â€œproduction-gradeâ€ more than just a buzzword.

OpenAI was recognized as an Emerging Leader in Gartnerâ€™s 2025 Innovation Guide for Generative AI Model Providers, joining the likes of Google, Anthropic, and AWS. Strong validation of multimodal and enterprise traction.

Cartesia was named a Twilio AI Startup Searchlight Award honoree, celebrating their work on natural, low-latency conversational intelligence for every device.

Google launched Nano Banana Pro and I must say I love it! Curious to see what multi-modal conversational AI applications will benefit most from it. Share what you've tinkered with! 

LiveKit rolled out three new products plus livekit-agents@1.3.3, solidifying its open-source foundation for building scalable voice agents.

Deepgram's Lauren Jo Sypniewski offered a behind-the-scenes look at how the team is solving real-time conversational challenges and scaling multilingual data, great insights for teams building human-like voice models.

Pipecat v0.0.95 shipped with ElevenLabs RealtimeTTS, ai-coustics VAD, and Hindi support for Rime â€” more tools for faster, more inclusive voice systems.

And if youâ€™re following the enterprise side of the field, these updates are all pointing to one thing: evaluation, latency, and orchestration are becoming the new frontier for production-ready agents.

Excited to announce our collaboration with Twilio on a deep dive into Voice AI reliability and evaluation!

It's about my hot take: If you're only measuring latency and word error rate, you're basically flying blind with your voice agents.

Imagine this - Your restaurant ordering bot might have perfect 300ms latency and 98% WER... but customers are still abandoning 40% of orders because it keeps asking for info they already gave or can't handle the sentence "actually, make that a large."

Technically perfect â‰  Business ready.
Here's where it gets good - technical metrics become diagnostic tools for business problems:

Low completion rates? â†’ Probably a context management issue
Going off-script? â†’ Prompt engineering needs work
Slow responses killing conversions? â†’ Model orchestration problem

That blog article broke down exactly how to map technical levers (knowledge base design, model selection, API orchestration) to business outcomes so you can actually prioritize what to fix.

Shoutout to Dan Bartlett and the Twilio team for pushing the conversation forward on production-grade voice AI ðŸš€

Full article in comments - worth the read if you're trying to get voice agents past the pilot stage.

Just went deep on the MLOps community Podcast about why Voice AI is eating customer support (and what's next)

80% of voice AI deployments are in customer support. But why? Turns out it's not just about cost savings. It's because:

--> Infrastructure already exists (phone lines = universal API)
--> SOPs are documented (agents know exactly what to say)
--> The channel is constrained (1:1 conversations are easier than group chaos)
--> Legacy systems don't need software integrations. everyone can just talk

The reliability piece gets spicy though. We're talking about :

--> Benchmarking every major STT/LLM/TTS provider on the cost-latency-quality triangle
--> Why 99th percentile latency matters more than averages (6 seconds = hangup)
--> How to give agents negotiation boundaries without them giving away the farm

Our convo also covered why doctors, truck drivers, and HVAC techs are the next wave; they're in cars/on-site all day with zero desire to adopt complex UIs. Voice just works.
Big thanks to Demetrios Brinkmann for the thoughtful convo and everyone at the Agent Builder Summit who built evals with us live ðŸš€

Link to full episode in comments. definitely worth a listen if you're shipping voice agents.

Your "Ask me anything" chatbot is probably a $500K mistake waiting to happen.

Hamel Husain just explained why in our podcast, and honestly it completely changed how I think about scoping voice AI products.

Every company wants their agent to "handle any customer question." Sounds amazing in the pitch deck, but here's the problem: when you promise "anything," you literally can't test it properly, evaluate success, or even know which failures are costing you customers.

Hamel calls this the evaluation death spiral = no clear scope means you can't define success metrics, which means you can't identify critical failures, which means you can't prioritize fixes. Your product slowly degrades and trust evaporates before you even realize what's happening.

The teams that actually win in voice AI? They get radically specific about what their agents will and won't do.

"This agent books appointments. Period."
"This agent answers billing questions. That's it."

I've watched companies spend 6 months building "ask me anything" agents that handle 100 use cases poorly. Then I've seen teams spend 6 weeks building agents for 3 use cases that actually work. Guess which ones are still in production 12 months later?

The uncomfortable truth is that your AI agent doesn't need more capabilities, it needs clearer boundaries. That's the only way to guarantee what it will actually do well. Are you brave enough to define what your agent won't do?

This was just one insight from my conversation with Hamel. We also went deep on how to actually perform effective error analysis for voice AI; the manual review process that most teams skip but can't automate away. If you're building conversational AI, the full episode is worth your time.

Link to the full conversation in the comments ðŸ‘‡

ðŸ§µ This week in Conversational AI ðŸ§µ 

Honestly, this week almost feels like ElevenLabs week! ElevenLabs Summit on 11/11 (thanks for having us!) â€“ the team used that opportunity to launch so many things! Make sure to check their announcements which range from new voices over to massive improvements to their agent platform. My highlight was Scribe v2 Realtime. They announced a 150ms response time, 90+ languages, and full privacy compliance. Let's see if it sets a new benchmark for real-time transcription! 

Harvey partnered with ElevenLabs to bring multilingual voice to the legal industry. Powered by ElevenLabsâ€™ speech models, Harvey can now communicate naturally across dozens of languages, dialects, and accents, making legal knowledge more accessible worldwide.

Meta open-sourced Omnilingual ASR, a suite of ASR models supporting 1600+ languages, from 300M to 7B parameters, plus a 350-language dataset. A huge step toward breaking global language barriers and expanding access to voice tech.

Hathora launched open weights for realtime inference, deployed across 14 regions for ultra-low latency and developer-friendly access. A major unlock for teams building the next generation of voice agents.

Tavus announced a $40M Series B (CRV, Sequoia, YC) and introduced Tavus PALs, emotionally intelligent, multimodal digital humans designed to understand, adapt, and evolve. Congrats team! ðŸ™ 

Berlin Brandenburg Airport said goodbye to call centers and hello to its new GenAI agent. Passenger satisfaction jumped to 85%+, costs dropped 65%, and wait times vanished. A powerful signal for what voice-first CX can achieve.

ðŸ£ And we closed the week hosting Syntax & Sushi at Coval, in partnership with Lily Clifford from Rime and Founders You Should Know - an intimate Voice AI dinner where both teams shared how we're building the future of voice from scratch. P.S: We're hiring!

Below is a picture that has nothing to do with conversational AI but me giving a ted talk on how to roll sushi

Autonomous cars still need safety drivers. Your customer support agent shouldn't.

Here's the difference: A self-driving car operates in an unpredictable physical world where stakes are life-or-death. But a customer support agent? It operates in a constrained environment with clear success metrics and reversible mistakes.
Yet most companies are deploying AI agents with the same caution Waymo used for cars on highways; humans monitoring every interaction, ready to intervene.

At Waymo, safety drivers were necessary because we couldn't simulate every real-world scenario. But in customer support, billing inquiries, and scheduling? We absolutely can. The infrastructure exists to test millions of conversational edge cases before a single customer interaction.

The companies winning with AI agents aren't the ones being most cautious. They're the ones who built evaluation systems rigorous enough to deploy with confidence.. with an autonomous safety net.

If you're at Cerebral Valley AI Summit today â€“ make sure to join my hosted discussion on this topic! 

And comment if you're interested in the takeaways!

Are you a talented engineer curious about voice AI? Do you like sushi? 

Tomorrow (11/13), we're hosting an exclusive dinner with early-stage voice AI founders Brooke Hopkins (Coval) and Lily Clifford (Rime).

Join us to hear unfiltered stories from founders and early employees about building voice AI tools from scratch. Plus, we'll be making our own sushi ðŸ˜‰ 

Only a few spots are left for exceptional job seeking engineers. Apply NOW to be considered: https://lnkd.in/gf-m76Wn

Thank you to Loren Phillips and the Coval team for hosting us!

ðŸ§µThis week in Conversational AI and wow, itâ€™s a big one:

Giga announced a $61M Series A led by Redpoint to scale its human-quality AI agent, real-time latency, natural tone, and already powering DoorDash across 40+ countries. A breakout moment for enterprise voice AI â€“ congrats team!

ElevenLabs dropped a huge update: hosted LLMs inside its Agents Platform. Their new GLM 4.5 Air and Qwen3 models deliver sub-150 ms response time and top-tier reasoning; at one-third the cost of alternatives. Real-time dialogue is officially here.

Rime took On-Prem out of beta! Itâ€™s built for customers who need the best in TTS, ultra-low latency, compliance, and local deployment. Enterprise-grade voice synthesis with full control.

A CX Today survey found that 82% of organizations expect AI to increase voice traffic. Live conversations remain the heartbeat of trust and loyalty in CX.
And another CX Today spotlight featured Glia and others rethinking contact center economics, using Voice AI to drive efficiency while amplifying human teams, not replacing them.
--> Will link them in the comments â€“ great reads. 

And Finally - Today marks the launch of the first Skool community dedicated to Open Source Voice AI! ðŸŽ‰ Nour Siakir Oglou is very active in the voice AI community and shares her journey from building with closed Voice AI platforms to embracing open source. Make sure to check it out! 

Watch out for Next Week â€“ Next Wednesday, LiveKit, Pipecat, Hathora, and Google are hosting a Voice AI Meetup with a Stealth Launch?! Drop your suspicions for what you think this launch will be! 

What did I miss this week?

Hot take: If you need a "996 culture" written into your company policy, you've already failed at hiring.

Real builders don't need to be forced. They choose the grind because they're obsessed with the problem.

This is Rhea Bryce Pokorny one year ago, after pulling an all-nighter to ship one of our first retention features (hence the sunglasses). back then, we were working out of my Oakland apartment.

Context: We just had a couple of customers. Our product was held together with duct tape and prayers. We were building features for problems our customers didn't even know they had yet (spoiler: they came knocking months later). Rhea saw the technical challenge and got excited. Not because I mandated overtime. Not because of some toxic "hustle culture" policy. Because she genuinely cared about what we were building.

She's there for every 2am outage. Every impossible deadline. Every "this needs to ship tomorrow to close the deal" moment. The features she's built have won us customers overnight. And she does it all without the ego you'd expect.

Here's what most founders miss:
When you're begging people to work hard, you've hired the wrong people. The right early team doesn't need convincing. They're the ones who want to be in the trenches. Who see a hard problem and think "challenge accepted" instead of "that's not in my job description." 

If your team needs a policy to work weekends, you don't have a culture problem. You have a hiring problem...

Coval is built on 10+ years of self-driving simulation expertise. I am not kidding!  Kobi Hudson is one of the most cracked engineers I've ever worked with and we're learning so much from him.

Today he walked us through how he's completely vetted our simulation infrastructure to handle massive enterprise loads. The parallels between voice infra and what he built at Waymo are absolutely wild. We're taking those lessons and building simulation pipelines that actually scale.

This is what happens when you hire world-class talent. One person can literally transform your entire product! 

This is a team where every single person operates at this level. The bar is exceptionally high, and we're keeping it there.

P.S: VERY Few seats left on the rocket ship ðŸš€ Know an engineer who should be building with us? Send them my way.

Is Voice AI entering its "trust economy" phase? Hear our take! 

The most recent episode of Conversations in Conversational AI was with a Coval customer - to give everyone here an understanding of how voice evals actually impact companies building at the frontier of voice AI in impactful industries.

michael j goh from Krew (building voice agents for credit servicing) nailed it: "If you've ever sat through a third-party risk management process, you're going to realize that a lot of it has got to do with trust."

Here's what changed for them:
---> They stopped treating evaluation as just internal QA.
---> They started using it as external validation.

Now when Krew walks into enterprise sales conversations, they bring third-party audit reports from Coval. Tens of thousands of documented tests. Independent validation they can literally print and hand to customers.

Mike's take: "It's a great report I can just send over and say, 'We did this internally, AND there's a trusted third party giving us the check mark.'"
QA became their sales accelerator.

Mike sees where this is going: "In the future, you're going to see way more requirement for third-party auditors to come in. Just like how we audit financial statements."

The winners won't be the ones with the slickest demos. They'll be the ones who can prove their agents work at scale.

Thanks for coming on the pod, Mike! Guys, go check out the incredible impact the Krew team is having in such a regulated industry ðŸ‘ Link in Comments!

Why buy ads when you can be one? Our marketing budget is frugal, so Iâ€™m spending Halloween as Coval's billboard; merchâ€™d up and fully sponsored by necessity. ðŸŽƒ

Anyways, Here's this week in conversational AI! 

At #ODSCWest, I shared lessons from training self-driving cars and how simulation-based testing can scale autonomous voice agents. The crowd was amazing, and the conversations around reliability and evals reminded me how quickly this field is maturing! 

Then came some monster-sized product news:
Cartesia raised $100M from Kleiner Perkins, Index, Lightspeed & NVIDIA and launched Sonic-3, a state-of-the-art real-time model with 90 ms latency, 42 languages, and full emotional range. Think: human warmth meets GPU speed. 

Krisp launched Turn-Taking v2, tackling one of voice AIâ€™s hardest problems â€” natural conversation flow. With better stability and noise robustness, itâ€™s a real step toward effortless, human-like dialogue.

Retell AI launched Components for AI Agents, reusable logic blocks that sync automatically across agents. No more copy-paste chaos; just consistent, maintainable design for enterprise-scale deployments.

Slack + OpenAI introduced Company Knowledge, using Slackâ€™s new RTS API to connect ChatGPT with your teamâ€™s internal context, delivering answers that actually understand your business.

ElevenLabs rolled out Agent Workflows, a visual editor for designing and routing subagents â€” simplifying how teams orchestrate multi-agent conversations while optimizing for latency, cost, and accuracy.

Lastly, weâ€™re thrilled that Coval was named among the most widely used tools for model evaluation by Iconiq Capital! â€“ alongside LangSmith, Galileo, and Weights & Biases. A strong signal that purpose-built eval frameworks are fast becoming core infrastructure for reliable AI agents. 

Itâ€™s a thrilling moment for the industry, voice systems are becoming faster, smarter, and eerily lifelike.

Almost little spooky how fast itâ€™s all evolving! ðŸŽƒ

What other launches did we miss?

Most AI agents work great in demos, but collapse when they hit real workflows.

MIT Sloan School of Management and Boston Consulting Group (BCG) found that 95% of GenAI pilots fail in production. Research shows billions invested in AI pilots yield zero ROI because companies avoid the "friction" that creates real value. 

If you want to build the infrastructure to fix that, and work with everyone building voice agents - from startups to unicorns - Coval is the place.

What makes us different: Our team brings combined decades of autonomous driving experience to testing production voice AI. We're applying the same safety-critical testing methodologies that make self-driving cars reliable to conversational AI agents.

The opportunity: Voice AI is moving from demos to production. Every company building agents needs a way to ensure they work reliably at scale. We're the reliability infrastructure layer making that possible across healthcare, finance, and beyond.

Why now: This isn't theoretical - we're already helping Fortune 500 companies test voice agents across hundreds of scenarios instead of manually checking each conversation. Real customers, real production systems, real ROI.

Early team, massive impact, solving the production AI reliability problem that's costing companies billions.

Interested in solving production AI reliability? Reach out!
#hiring #ai

author.headline: AI Simulation+Evals @ Coval | Former Eng @ Zoox / Amazon Self-Driving | D1 All-American

data.text:
Huge congrats to the Cartesia team on launching Sonic-3, their latest streaming text-to-speech model! 

What makes sonic 3 special:

---> Emotion and laughter support that brings real expressiveness to voice synthesis, all while keeping the same lightning-fast latency. Check out my example in the video :-) 
---> 190ms median latency for real-time conversations
---> 27 new languages & 100 new voices that sound super natural
---> fine-grained speed and volume controls

Aaand of course, we added sonic 3 to the Coval benchmarks so now everyone can test it out and compare performance against other solutions.

We also just launched a new TTS playground where you can hear the emotion-driven synthesis for yourself.

Kudos to the Cartesia team for pushing what's possible in voice AI!

ðŸ—£ï¸ This week in Conversational AI:

Vogent just released Vogent-Turn-80M, a state-of-the-art turn-detection model that listens to conversations to detect when to wait and when to speak. Who tried it? Congrats on the launch, Jagath V. and Vignesh Varadarajan!

An article in CX Today highlighted how AI-generated voice fraud has become the new threat vector for contact centers â€” fraudsters are using voice cloning and IVR mining to exploit the voice channel's security gaps, while undertrained agents remain vulnerable to manipulation. The solution seems obvious to me: Evals!

Sesame, a conversational AI and smart glasses startup founded by Oculus co-founder Brendan Iribe, just raised $250M in Series B funding from Sequoia and Spark. Their breakthrough tech synthesizes speech end-to-end (capturing emotion and rhythm like real human dialogue) and already saw over 1 million users interact with their AI voices Maya and Miles, generating 5+ million minutes of talk time within weeks of launching. Congrats!

And a fun one for the end: Clippy is back! Microsoftjust dropped Mico, an AI-powered blob that's basically Clippy 2.0 for the Copilot era. This expressive little guy changes colors, reacts to your conversations, remembers what you tell it; and if you tap it enough times, it literally transforms back into the OG Clippy paperclip. getting nostalgia! 

What did I miss this week?

The Voice mafia showed up in full force last night.

Deepgram's open house was absolutely packed. And what a week for Coval! we spent time with their team during their offsite sharing insights from our voice AI simulation & benchmarking work, then connected with their whole partner ecosystem over drinks.

The energy around voice AI right now is insane. It feels like the early smartphone era, and almost like an "oh shit, everything just changed" moment when the iPhone dropped and everyone realized mobile would reshape everything. I felt it being in that room last night. Everyone's locked in, because something real is shifting with voice AI, and we're still super early! 

Thank you for having us, Deepgram Team! 
Loren Phillips Klaudia Guzij

One of the biggest inspirations & nudges to start my own "Conversations in Conversational AI" podcast was actually my very first own podcast recording for SuperDataScience! Can't believe this is now almost 10 months ago. Btw - everything I mentioned back then is still very relevant! Make sure to give it a listen. 

Who should be on my next episode of "Conversations in Conversational AI"? drop your suggestions!

AI agents aren't sold like software, they're hired like employees.

Had a conversation about AI agent evals that really clicked something into place. With normal SaaS, you see a demo, check the features, and you're good. 

We've basically solved reliability for software. if your app can't hit 99.99% uptime, something's seriously wrong.

But agents are a totally different game. The question shifts from "what can it do?" to "how well does it actually perform?"

This creates a mess for buyers: you're basically forced to run expensive pilots because there's no way to evaluate quality until the thing is live in production. 
It's slow, costly, and half the time you still don't have clear answers.

Three things that jumped out:
--> Voice AI is sneaking into old-school industries (logistics, healthcare) because only one side needs to adopt. One company automates, the other stays human. No coordination required, no "everyone needs to switch" problem.

--> Evaluation can't just be a post-purchase thing. It needs to happen from the first demo through pilots and into production. Building trust earlier makes pilots way more efficient and focused.

--> This could become the "SOC 2 for agents." Not just risk mitigation; a way to unlock enterprise deals by proving your agent actually works and meets compliance standards.

The self-driving car comparison is pretty on point: you can't just build the tech. You need serious testing, simulation across tons of scenarios, and clear standards before anyone trusts it in the real world.

The enterprises building agents internally (and there are a lot) need control over their customer experience. They're not outsourcing their secret sauce, they want tools to measure, validate, and continuously improve how their agents perform.

What are you seeing with AI agent adoption? Are evaluation standards starting to emerge in your space?

We're excited to join Deepgram for their AI Open House in San Francisco on October 22nd! ðŸŽ‰

Coval and Deepgram work together to help enterprises evaluate and benchmark voice AI models. Join us alongside teams from Vapi, Daily, and LiveKit for an evening of great conversations about the future of voice AI.

ðŸ“… Wednesday, October 22, 2025 | 5:30 â€“ 8:00 PM
Signup link is in the comments!

ðŸ§µ This week in Conversational AI ðŸ§µ 

Salesforce Dreamforce comes with great announcements in conversational AI! First of all, they introduced Agentforce Voice, a new feature in its AI-powered customer service platform that enables voice-based customer interactions, allowing AI agents to answer calls, customize tone and pronunciation, and integrate with major phone systems. Then â€“ we hear that ElevenLabs joined the conference to talk about how they're part of powering the voice of Agentforce. And finally, Salesforce relaunched Slack as â€œthe new agentic OS for work,â€ integrating AI agents, CRM data, and contextual intelligence into one workspace to transform how teams collaborate, make decisions, and boost productivity. What other Dreamforce announcements did I miss?

Microsoft announced the introduction of sensitive data redaction in their Contact Center, enabling privacy-first voice AI experiences by automatically removing sensitive information from recordings, transcripts, and logs. 

ElevenLabs is hosting it'sElevenLabs Summit soon! On Nov 11, they're bringing together the leaders shaping the future of voice-first interfaces.

Deepgram is hosting a massive happy hour in SF n October 22nd! We're excited to join the team for their AI Open House. Coval and Deepgram work together to help enterprises evaluate and benchmark voice AI models. Join us alongside teams from Vapi , Daily , and LiveKit for an evening of great conversations about the future of voice AI. Link in the comments! 

Reddit expanded its AI-powered conversational search feature, Reddit Answers, to five new languages: French, German, Spanish, Italian, and Portuguese. making it available in countries like Brazil, France, Germany, Spain, and Mexico. 

Walmart Ã— OpenAI partner on a generative AI shopping assistant powered by Voicee LLCâ€™s patented voice technology, ushering in the era of conversational commerce and validating foundational IP in voice-driven AI.

Let me know what else happened this week!

The real speed hack for conversational AI? Evals.

Andrew Ng just called it: the no.1  predictor of how fast you ship AI agents isn't your model choice or your tech stack - it's having disciplined evals and error analysis.

Here's the problem: Voice and chat agents fail in way more ways than traditional ML. Latency issues. Bad interruption handling. Off-script responses. Workflow breaks. Without proper testing, you're flying blind, discovering bugs in production, and iterating in slow motion.

This is where Coval changes the game:

1. Ship faster
Stop building eval infrastructure from scratch. We give you audio metrics, LLM judges, workflow verification; everything you need to test comprehensively from day one. Teams go from prototype to production-ready in weeks instead of quarters.

2. Iterate with confidence
Simulate hundreds of realistic conversations overnight. Spot regressions instantly. Know exactly what changed and why. No more "let's deploy and see what happens."

3. Turn testing into selling (!)
Here's the bonus: your evaluation results become your best sales tool. Share public dashboards showing 95%+ resolution rates. Let prospects see exactly how your agent handles edge cases. Data-driven demos close deals.

4. Keep improving in production
Push live calls through the same metrics. Catch issues early. Feed real edge cases back into your test suite. The feedback loop never stops.

Bottom line: Teams using Coval ship 3-5x faster because they're not guessing but they're measuring and fixing what matters.

Like Andrew says: Focus on systematic evaluation...That's how you win.

I met Al Gore!!! And guess what? He's super passionate about voice AI!

Not a surprise to me, though. Voice AI has the opportunity to solve many urgent systems-level challenges and opportunities in the next 5 years.
The big question is whether voice will just be a better interface or if it will actually become the dominant intelligent layer mediating all human-machine interaction. I bet you know where I stand on this :-) 

It's been an absolute honor to be part of the discussion on this topic with a group of leading voice AI providers, buyers, and decision-makers. 
Scaling Voice AI safely has been a major focus of mine, and having Coval be part of this conversation confirms that we're working on something that truly matters. 

As an independent provider, Coval is enabling voice AI companies to scale safely and reliably while acting as an independent trust layer. We've got your back when it comes to scaling! 

I'm thrilled to be part of this incredible journey, and I can't wait to see where voice AI takes us in the future!
Awesome energy at the Coval Daily Langfuse  Boundary (YC W23) AI Tinkerers Tavus  Y Combinator Voice AI Hackathon today!!

ðŸ§µ This week in conversational AI:

ðŸ’¥ ð—¢ð—½ð—²ð—»ð—”ð—œ ð——ð—²ð˜ƒð——ð—®ð˜† ðŸ®ðŸ¬ðŸ®ðŸ± set a new bar, unveiling GPT-5 Pro, AgentKit, and the Apps SDK, giving developers everything to build eval-ready, high-reliability conversational agents. Plus, apps inside ChatGPT officially make conversation the new OS.

ðŸŽ¤ Coval hosted the Voice AI community in SoMa following DevDay. Sharing real-world lessons from teams shipping production-grade agents. We talked about how frameworks from autonomous driving, alignment and denoising are reshaping how we build reliable voice systems.

ðŸ’¬ Cresta â€™s â€œState of Voice AIâ€ panel during #SFTechWeek brought together an incredible lineup â€” Corinne Marie Riley (Greylock Partners), Karan Goel (Cartesia), Kwindla Hultman Kramer (Daily), Brooke Hopkins (Coval), and Daniel Hoske (Cresta). A thoughtful discussion on how enterprise AI and voice platforms are evolving â€” and where reliability, ethics, and UX converge.

ðŸ’¼ Salesforce launched Agentforce, declaring â€œthe era of reactive customer support is over.â€ Their new AI-powered CRM brings proactive, autonomous engagement into enterprise workflows â€” a major signal of maturity for agentic systems.

ðŸ§© ElevenLabs made big moves this week! Releasing open-source UI components for AI audio + voice apps, launching Agent Workflows to orchestrate multi-agent logic and human hand-offs, and announcing a partnership with Sharpen as its exclusive AI voice provider. Together, these launches signal ElevenLabsâ€™ push to become the go-to infrastructure layer for voice-first, agentic AI.

ðŸ“ˆ The conversational AI market keeps accelerating â€” projected to grow from $12.8B in 2025 to $136B by 2035, driven by enterprise deployment and multimodal interaction.

ðŸš€ Big week for conversational AI!

From watching incredible launches at OpenAI DevDay to hosting the Voice AI community at our office... yesterday was exactly why I love SF.

Loren Phillips and I talked about applying lessons from self-driving to voice AI â€“ specifically around human alignment and denoising. Turns out the frameworks for building safe autonomous vehicles translate pretty well to building reliable voice agents.

The highlight was definitely having michael j goh from Krew (a Coval customer!) jump on stage to share how they prioritize agent reliability for their end customers. Real-world insights from someone shipping in production hit different.

Thank you to everyone who came out to SoMa!

There are enough OpenAI Dev Day posts out there so I'll summarize my thoughts in a line: Having robust and reliable ways to evaluate model performance is just as important (if not more important) than building the models themselves. #openai #devday Brooke Hopkins

It's an honor to be part of #SFTechWeek and share this momentum with everyone coming into the city. Let's make it a good one!

ðŸ§µ This week in conversational AI:

Can't believe it's already Friday! But wow â€” what a WEEK. Seriously, if you blinked you missed about 10 major launches. Here's everything that just dropped (I probably missed so much as well)

ðŸ”— LiveKit launches Inference --> One API key to rule them all. Access OpenAI, DeepMind, ElevenLabs, AssemblyAI and more through a single integration. If you've been juggling multiple voice AI providers, this just became your new best friend. Finally, someone solved the "which provider do I use?" problem with actual infrastructure ðŸ”¥

ðŸŽ¤ Hume AI drops OCTAVE e 2 --> 11 languages. Instant voice cloning. 40% faster. Half the cost. This is the kind of upgrade that makes you rethink your entire voice stack. Multilingual voice realism just took a massive leap forward, and your TTS budget is about to thank you.

resharedPost.text:
ðŸŽ‰ Exciting News! Please join us in welcoming Rob Young to the Coval team! 

Before joining Coval, he led design for Google Inbox, the first version of Creative Cloud at Adobe, multiple products at Apple, has been a First Round Fast Track mentor, and founded and led the product design studio OM. As you can see, Rob brings a wealth of experience crafting elegant, user-centered experiences at some of the world's most innovative companies.

Design is at the center of Coval - we want to build beautiful products that make deploying complex and messy autonomous systems simple. And Rob is just the right person to lead this.

Outside of work, you'll find Rob spending time with his family, skateboarding, doing yoga, and painting.

Welcome to the team, Rob!Â ðŸŽ‰

data.text:
So excited for Rob Young to join Coval! He has built some of my favorite products. I was an early user of Google Inbox and loved how it reimagined what email could be - superhuman before superhuman was cool.

On top of that Rob has such a high level of agency & brings so much more to Coval than only design. He spins up cursor, already pushes changes to the front-end, and re-imagines new ways how we can make insights from your conversational evals educational and actionable at the same time. So hyped for the upcoming changes to the Coval app!

We believe the voice AI community deserves real benchmarks, not marketing claims.

That's why we've been pushing transparency at Coval â€” and it was incredible to see Scott Stephenson from Deepgram give us a shoutout for it at VapiCon.

This just happened at the first-ever Voice AI Summit that Vapi put together. The energy was unreal. Got the whole voice AI community in one room. Builders showing off new architectures, real conversations about what's working, and a genuine sense that we're early to something big.

Michael Seibel said it best: "Voice AI has the potential to move the needle for enterprise in a way unprecedented by B2B SaaS."

The infrastructure is ready. The community is moving fast. Enterprise is waking up to it. Excited to keep building and sharing what we learn!

What if voice AI worked more like your brain and less like a chain of text prompts?

That's the vision Scott Stephenson shared on our latest podcast, and Deepgram's new Flux model is the first step toward making it real.
We had the honor of being among the first to test Flux and include it in Coval's benchmarking suite. The difference? Immediately apparent.

What makes Flux different:
--> Over 50% lower latency to first token vs Nova-3
--> Built-in end-of-turn detection (no separate VAD needed)
--> Zero accuracy tradeoff: same WER as Nova-3, dramatically faster

But here's what got me most excited: Flux is just the beginning of Deepgram's "Neuroplex" architecture: a system designed like the human brain, where specialized regions work together through connected context (think: gray matter + white matter for AI).

Right now, most voice systems flatten everything into text streams, losing crucial context about tone, timing, language, and turn-taking. Neuroplex changes that by passing rich, multi-track context through every layer of the stack.
The implications? Voice agents that don't just sound human; but understand and respond like humans do.

We're tracking Flux and the evolution it against all other STTs on benchmarks[dot]coval[dot]ai. Also make sure to check out our playground where you can compare it live! (link in the comments) 

Aaand finally: catch the full conversation with Scott on Coval's Conversations in Conversational AI podcast. We dive deep into why context is the next frontier after solving latency and interruptions.

Congrats on the Launch!

ðŸŒŠ Mark your calendars!

On October 8, Cresta is hosting The State of Voice AIâ€”a private #SFTechWeek event bringing together the builders and thought leaders shaping the future of voice technology.

Seats are limited! Approved guests will receive a confirmation email.

#SFTechWeek #Networking #VoiceAI #TechCareers #FutureOfWork

"If people lose trust in your evals - they lose trust in you."
This is exactly why you need human alignment in your Evals!

If there's ONE thing you listen to this weekend, make it Lenny Rachitsky's latest podcast episode with Hamel H. and Shreya Shankar. They absolutely demolish common misconceptions about AI evals and drive home why you need to LOOK! AT! THE! DATA!

Key takeaways:
â†’ Evals are becoming the new PRDs for AI products (told ya!)
â†’ Error analysis should ALWAYS come before writing evals
â†’ LLM-as-judge without human oversight is fundamentally flawed

We're building a conversational AI evals platform â€“ of course our goal is to automate the most annoying part of doing evals (think: metric infrastructure, audio-evals, dashboard setups, etc.). 
But here's the thing: we've had human-in-the-loop systems for our LLM-as-a-Judge metrics from day one because we learned this lesson early.
Anyone selling you on "just use our LLM-Judge prompts to auto-eval your voice/chat agent" is selling you BS. 

The most successful AI products aren't just technically sound; they're built on evaluation systems that people actually trust. And trust requires human judgment, especially in the messy, nuanced world of conversational AI.

Thank you, Lenny Rachitsky for bringing Hamel's & Shreya's Eval Bible to people's attention ðŸ™
coval philosophy in a nutshell

If the most important metric you care about is deflection rate, you're ngmi. 

Everyone celebrates high call deflection rates as success stories. But here's what's really happening:

A Customer calls about a billing dispute. The voice agent provides scripted responses, never understands the real problem, and the customer eventually hangs up in frustration.

âœ… Call deflection rate: 100%
âŒ Reality: Transcript shows "This is so stupid, I can't believe this"

The dashboard looks perfect. The customer experience is terrible.
I've been talking to companies implementing voice AI, and the pattern is consistent: teams optimize for deflection without measuring customer sentiment the right way. They only discover the disasters through one-off transcript reviews. 

This is why customer satisfaction often plummets even as voice AI "performance" improves. The solution isn't scrapping voice agents, but measuring what actually matters:

- Did the caller's problem get solved?
- How did they sound during the interaction?
- Were escalation policies followed accurately?
- Did they call back immediately after?

More companies are using Coval to run systematic evaluations on their voice calls, identifying which conversation flows create genuinely frustrated customers versus helpful experiences.

Voice AI should solve problems efficiently, not just deflect them away from humans...

Trend I'm following: evals quickly becoming a must-have skill for product builders (and AI companies).

It's the first new hard skill in a long time that PMs/engineers/founders have had to learn to be successful. The last one was maybe SQL, and Excel?

Evals have been one of the most common themes in my podcast conversations, when I ask guests what skills people need to develop to be successful with the rise of AI.

Also:
- Garry Tan: "Evals are emerging as the real moat for AI startups."
- Kevin Weil: "Writing evals is going to become a core skill for product managers."
- Mike Krieger: "Writing evals is probably the most important thing right now."
- Sarah Guo: "Evals = your new marketing."
- Greg Brockman: "Evals are surprisingly often all you need."
- Brendan Foody (CEO of arguably the fastest growing company in history, quote below)

More to come.
